poem:
Title: Upon Delistings

In the heart of the ancient City,
The pulse slows, stalls - a lament, quiet,
Numbers tumble from a stock market's heights,
Beneath the cobbled streets, a secret exodus.
Only 738 remain, a worried whisper
in the cool London air,
And the City, an old trader, listens, waits,
While the forgotten echo of 70 losses
weaves uncertainty through its towers.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Sharp rise in Aim delistings casts doubt over City of London’s future The number of companies delisting from London’s junior stock market has risen sharply in the last year, adding to concerns about the future of the City’s financial sector. In the past 12 months the number of companies on the Alternative Investment Market (Aim) has fallen by 70 to 738 at the end of March, according to London Stock Exchange Group data. That is". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
